Hi Physics Girl! Great video on the physics part! Although I think you're mixing the whole process between the touch and the poop emoji... The touch-screen signals the operating system the position of the finger's touch, not the code that uniquely identifies the poop emoji. That way the operating system knows where the user touches the screen, and in your case, in the keyboard with the poop emoji, that will communicate with the messages app the poop emoji which has that unicode to uniquely identify it and write it on the text field.

The explanation of the sensing hardware is interesting, but the chip that magically turns the sensor's input into a poop emoji is glossing over a lot of details. Obviously jumping straight to the full, actual details would be ridiculously overwhelming, but in my opinion it would have been more meaningful to explain that the chip hooked up to the sensor turns the input into information about where the touch is -- X, Y coordinates, size of touch and intensity of touch -- and then that information is passed to the processor which can decide that a touch at a particular place on the screen means a poop emoji. Also, that binary you listed out isn't the actual character code, it's encoded in a special format created to let older systems support more than 255 unique characters. I looked it up and as a straight number, the poop emoji (official name "Pile of Poop") is U+1F4A9, which in binary is 00000000 0000001 11110100 10101001. When computers talk to each other, they usually use a different "encoding" called UTF-8, and what you showed is the poop emoji in UTF-8 -- but the computer can't directly process the data in that form, because the bits of actual data are spread out unevenly across bytes and different characters can be different numbers of bytes long. A magical touch-to-emoji chip wouldn't be producing the encoded form directly, as that's only used when going "over the wire" to servers and the like.
That's not now it works though... Your touch on the screen isn't translated into the 32 bits of ANY  emoji. It's translated into an x,y coordinate.
very good video, what studies do you have?

4:13 To be exact, that's actually UTF-8 encoding of the poop emoji (U+1F4A9 PILE OF POO). The same character has different binary representation in other encodings. The sad fact is that we still (year 2021) don't have a worldwide agreement how to encode even a simple letter like "ä" or "µ". The UTF-8 encoding is the best option we have but still way too many programmers fail to support it correctly and use UCS-2 or US ASCII instead or some random 8-bit encoding which is called "code page" in Windows.

Unicode does not assign bit sequences to “characters”, it assigns them cardinals (numbers), called code points, kind of, with a more brother definition of ”characters”, Unicode actually assign them non-unique combinations of cardinals, as there are also variant selectors and grapheme clusters. Encodings assign them bit sequences, but not necessarily unique ones or to unique characters. The most popular one that fully supports Unicode is UTF-8, which you where using for your poop, and which does assign unique bit sequences to unique code points, but not to characters. As Unicode provides to ways to create for example ö, so does UTF-8, and other more complex grapheme.

þ is not actually unique to Icelandic. Icelandic is just the only still living language that still has it. It was also used in other Norse languages: Old Swedish, Old Norse, Gothic, and Middle English, as well as even Old English, which to my understanding is unlike Middle English not closely related to Old Norse.

From a Programmer's perspective, I'd like to add one thing... The touch screen contact point is translated into an X-Y coordinate, and the programmer uses it as a coordinate to determine what you touched (which button, image or anything else).  Leave the complicated stuff to the hardware guy.  For the programmer it's just a message signal with X and Y coordinates.

3:58 Very, very simplified. Well, it has to be, I suppose. However... 4:14 This is the UTF-8 encoding of that character. UTF-8 is used for storage and interchange, but not generally for internal representation; for that, it's much more likely to use something like UTF-16 or UCS-4. Also, all of these encodings are part of Unicode, and it's not even clear yet that you're touching a button (what's a button, anyway? the chip has no concept of that), so you're getting a little ahead of things. In reality, the chip is most likely figuring out the coordinates of where you're touching. This then gets sent to the operating system (still simplified), which then notifies the app that is currently displayed. The app figures out what touchable widget is at those coordinates, finds out it's the button for "insert the U+1F4A9* character", then adds that character to the string in the text box. Later on, assuming whatever protocol the app is using requires UTF-8 encoding, it converts the whole string to UTF-8, so that U+1F4A9 gets converted to the representation shown at 4:14.

* "U+####" is standard human-readable notation for Unicode code points, with the value in hexadecimal.

Nice video - great explanation of touch screens.But saying that capacitive touchscreens are accurate is like saying that news are better on digital tv (with 2-5 seconds delay). I had a pocket PC with resistive screen (when windows mobile was a thing) with onscreen keyboard that had letters half the size of the smallest android phone and I rarely missed a key. Yes, capacitive screens don't drift over time and you don't have to calibrate it but they are far from accurate. Plus they are often disturbed by other electric signals including switching power supplies. Even with relatively good, original brand power supplies some phones start to miss touches. The future is not always bright.

How close are we to using scalar fields for wireless communications? Or faster than c so to speak. Quoting David Wenbert "Let them all have The Big Secret:  that 'Voltage' is FASTER than 'Current', and that fast switching can exploit this, drawing on any source of ambient electrons in the environment (earth, air, water). Its ultimately how ALL FE/OU devices work; Bearden was right - establish the Dipole, and switch so that it is never discharged/shorted and you can draw free current forever. Voltage propagates faster (up to at least 8x "c", speed of light), whereas current in a solid conductor propagates at something slightly less than "c". That's IT, that's the Secret.

In her case a computer chip only works with electrical current in which 5V and above means 1 and any voltage below is interpreted as 0. As a computer scientist it's actually far more complicated from an abstract point of view. Then it's not just electrical current looping around gates, then it's software which manipulates all those patterns and that happens firstly in machine level, then low level, then high level, then application level! The packet carrying the poop character is forwarded from the NIC to the router, from the router it's forwarded to your street network where one of the switches then forward the packet further to a less and less local area until it gets to the server of the messaging application and the person "receiving" your message downloads the poop character onto their page so that they can also see the poop character you sent.

That binary sequence (that makes the poop emoji), does not actually have the information of where each pixel should be and what color to make a poop coil. But its just a reference that one phone is sending to another phone, since they both use the same unicode, the other phone will understand the reference. Its similar to a language. If i say "poop" in english to you, you would only understand my reference if you spoke English. That's very different from holding out an actual poop in my hand for you to look at, which is not a reference, but the actual object which is language independent.

Your first minute and half in the video is not correct. Balance of charge and stuff. Instead, scann of array of electrodes is done by measuring capacitive reactance (Zc), which may be expressed by formula Zc=1/(2*Pi*f*C), where Zc is capacitive reactance, Pi is 3.14..., f is frequency, and C is capacitance. We may call this capacitive reactance also capacitive impedance. By measuring transferred charge from one electrode to another by formula above (you may imagine it as a resistor), where one pairs of electrodes sending RF signal with fixed strength , while other pairs measuring voltage transferred by VARIABILITY of capacitive reactance depending of how much capacitance is added by conductive object (fingers, metals...). This scan is very fast, and usually uses more than one scan to be sure where exactly your fingers touched, then compare the result and MCU (MicroControler Unit) make decision how to interpret readings. The rest of your video is about right. There is too much technical data to shrink in such short video. Anyway, I enjoyed waching your videos about physics. Thanks.

Hey, Diana! I like your channel. I have a fun thought experiment about relativity that I'm not sure what the correct results would be. It could be a nice idea for one of your future videos. I hope you could make some animations to help me visualize it. I am one of your subscribers. ;)

The experiment goes like this:

Suppose there is an infinite plane of lights flashing on and off periodically, for example on for 5s and off for 5s (no gradual change), and all the lights are flashing in unison. An observer is looking at the plane of lights at a distant L perpendicular from the plane. What would the observer see if the observer is a) at rest relative to the plane b) moving away from the plane c) toward the plane d) parallel to the plane at a constant speed v (possibly greater than speed of light) and e) accelerating in the mentioned directions? Also, f) how should the lights flash in order for the observer to see them flashing together and g) how would it change if he starts moving?

My guess is that he sees concentric circles of on and off lights spreading out instead of all the lights flashing simultaneously. Another variation of the problem is to replace the plane with a sphere enclosing the observer, but that's probably too much to ask. However, thank you for reading this kinda long comment.

This video is too much oversimplified to be interesting or useful. You wanted to cover too many completely different topics. You even lie: there is no such a thing as unicode decoder chip. That's the key point of smartphones! Choose smaller topics, and get back to your usual, carefully structured videos :-)

Thorn (þ U+00FE Þ U+00DE) and Eth (ð U+00F0 Ð U+00D0) are both valid  English  characters... through about the 16þ century. They fell out of use about the Renaissance...  Along with Middle English Wynn (ƿ U+01BF Ƿ U+01F7) and Yogh (ȝ U+021D Ȝ U+021C)... The long S (ſ u+017F) was in use into the 1920's in the US (I've encountered it in both handwritten and printed matter in government records), but largely left favor in the last two decades of the 19th C. A number of odd characters are used in one or two languages, but included in Unicode as much for historical work as for their current use. More amusingly, I've met non-icelandic kids with the names Ðor and Þor, noting they used icelandic spellings.

Technically Unicode character numbers do not represent any specific set of bits. The binary representation is determined by the character encoding. UTF-8 is the most widely used encoding and best in most cases. But there's an complicated and messy history behind all that.

A basic overview of the networking aspect is that the phone constantly senses nearby radio towers (each at the center of a 'cell', thus 'cellular network') and chooses one to connect with, typically based on signal strength. The phone and cell tower communicate by sending electromagnetic waves outward from themselves in a spherical shape. The antennas on the cell tower focus their signal energy in one part of their spheres (horizontally outward from the tower in specific directions), while the phone's antenna is intended to distribute energy evenly in all directions because it doesn't know where the tower is. If you picture a sphere with your phone at the center and the nearest cell tower at the outer edge, the ratio of the size of the cell tower's antenna to the surface area of that sphere tells you the tiny fraction of the phone's transmitted energy that's received by the tower. The weakness of the received signals, combined with the fact that there are often millions of other signals of different types overlapping in all directions, means that there needs to be very complicated methods of filtering out noise, as well as extra data being sent for error detection/correction, and serious legal regulation to separate and restrict the use of the electromagnetic field

When connected to this wireless cell network, the phone sends the text data enclosed by packet data (the start and end of the packet, in terms of time they're sent, enclose the text data), which is like an addressed envelope around your text so the network knows where to deliver it to. Once received by a computer at the cell tower, this packet might actually get put inside another packet with better address data once the network figures out where in the world the recipient is. The packet of data is then placed into a 'frame' of data, which is more like a train car than an envelope, and this frame is sent as bursts of non-visible laser light into an optical fiber. The packet will be removed from the frame and examined at another node in the network, then sent off again. This process may be repeated many times depending on how far away the person you're texting is, until the packet gets to the right cell tower address and is sent to the recipient's phone

Smart phones are the embodiment of the true power of electromagnetism in all it's forms.

They have highly engineered tangible properties (which arise from electromagnetic properties on the molecular scale). They employ all kinds of chemical reactions (also electromagnetic). They have magnets inside them. They have electrical circuits.

Their displays are visible light.

And they communicate with the world using radio signals.

I must say, I still somewhat miss those days when we had resistive touch screens rather than the capacitive ones of today. On my Palm Pilot in the 90s, I could use a screw or a nail to input anything, and even better: It was 1-pixel-accurate! While nowadays, you get an accuracy of about 5mm at best, and that's still wat too much for some graphical user interfaces of certain apps, because things are positioned too closely together (or sometimes even for a simple keyboard on a smaller-ish screen). The last smartphone I had with a resistive touch screen was the glorious Nokia N900, and while it ran an awesome operating system that has its capabilities unmatched by anything available today (except the SailfishOS by the Finnish company Jolla), one other thing I was really fond of was its stylus, which had a pointy plastic tip about the diameter of a ballpoint pen. The signals I was able to send to this phone with this totally different technology are unrepresented in accuracy by any phone or tablet that's available today. Please start making phones with resistive touch again! And with SailfishOS, since it's so much like a standard Linux OS you'd run on your PC...
There's at least 10,000 times more computer power in your smartphone than all the computers that were used to put men on the moon.

On some phones you can actually see the capacitive touch grid of your screen. Just hold it so that it reflects the sun (while not caring about whether you see what's displayed on the screen, or even with the screen being off), and you will see a regular pattern of dots. That's at least part of the capacitive touch grid. I was able to see this on a Sony phone as well as on a Huawei phone from like 5 years ago.
